header.relationships: Close family, partners, very close friends
header.topics: Food and drink, neighbours, work, money, crime, mobile phones
header.activity: Mother and daughter having tea together.

was she er did she look of Indian origin?

ah yeah she said she'd driven past it and then come back
and while I was waiting at the bus stop there was this weird bloke
pff kept on trying to make conversation but
well first of all he said have you been waiting long?
and I said no not long and then it was have you got the time? So I told him the time
W er then he said something about everybody who went past and I'm not sure that he knew everybody that went past he was saying

and I'm sure as I say he didn't know half of them um and then he said oh there were er there was a bus came past that had got sorry not in service on and he said oh this is no good it's gonna be late and then he was talking on his mobile phone er very loudly
I hate it when people do that
and I thought he was a very strange person
speak on their er mobiles really loudly
and I hate it when you're on the bus and they're on their mobile phone and it's I'm on the bus
so do you not think he was just trying to chat you up?
mm mm I wouldn't have thought so
at least I desperately hope it wasn't that
you do get a lot of wierdos in
not saying only weirdos would try and chat you up but
I'm very pleased you made that clear
no there are there's always a crazy person walking along Ruchi's road shouting on his own beating his chest or

well it's always had that reputation
yeah but I don't see the connection between Bohemian and crazy
well you often get people who are a little mm challenged will congregate in a less conventional area
Cos I think they don't feel quite so out of place
oh I thought it was because um a lot of the crazies and I'm not saying crazy as a er derogatory term I'm saying is people who er do actually have um something wrong with them and
for that reason they're shouting to the skies they tend to beg on the high street and I think it's because it's such a hub
of activity there's always a lot of people there
I'd assume that it was for that reason
well I er expect that's part of it but again the people who come to beg in all probability don't live in the area

they come into that area because they know the pickings are good I think that's er it's like Solihull I'm sure we get an awful lot of these Eastern European concertina players who really can't play at all uh there were a there was a couple two men a couple of weeks ago I've seen them before one plays the saxophone and one has a concertina and they were playing the same tune
and it wasn't even quite the right tune
it was painful and there's a woman an Eastern European woman who plays sits and plays and she can't play at all she's not playing a tune she's just playing a random selection of notes and it uh
I think er they do it so that you pay them to stop playing
yeah It's like the guy with the bagpipes
he plays outside um Marks and Spencers and it's quite a local joke er people go past and say we're paying you to stop
He takes it in very good
oh dear and he plays quite well it's not that he plays badly it's just that the bagpipes are not everybody's cup of tea
A bit of a drone aren't they
well it's best heard from a distance
and actually from a distance it's quite a pleasant sound but when it's right up close it isn't a pleasant sound
unless you're passionately Scottish of course and then it doesn't really matter
well in Spain they'd have the gypsies going round
um round the streets with their what do you call it? The electronic keyboards
yeah you get it in main square
but they also get a shopping trolley and make a sound system
so they have really loud loud speakers
the automatic er rhythm that I used
casio keyboard dum de de dum dum
dum de de dum dum dum de de dum dum dum and uh that at eight o'clock on Sunday morning and you'd get people r er
leaning out of their windows throwing them coins and saying

the children they were all filthy dirty as well and I'm not sure whether that was done deliberately to gain sympathy
well anyone who has to resort to begging would get my sympathy I don't know whether they'd get my money
well the problem is that over here begging has become a profession it's not they don't do it because they have to do it
er no but is that through necessity cos they can't get a job?
no because it's the easy option they can earn as much money mm depending on where they go in a day than they could earn in an ordinary job
well I'm sure that there's a lot of people who are begging that would prefer to have a job
well I haven't done a survey so I wouldn't know but it is quite common that they earn considerably more than they would do doing a er minimum wage job
and of course they don't pay taxes and but they still qualify they they qualify for benefits they still get benefits seems a crazy system to me but hey what do I know?

well with a minimum wage job not being able to pay er for a living not to be ab not is huh not being a living wage I'm not surprised that people take other avenues to get the money that they need to live er and then get a bit cheeky
but there are people who do live on er on the minimum wage
well I doubt they er make ends meet very comfortably
well most people who are on minimum wage qualify for benefits as well so it's not they're not totally dependent on
and especially if they've got children and very often they will get housing allowance and things like that which makes their rents much more affordable

huh I think now it's about it's six pounds something an hour
or seven pounds an hour something like that
so what would that be like in a yearly figure? If you
um puh depends on how many hours a week you work
like if er if you're working full-time hours

if you're working a forty-hour week which is about two hundred and eighty pounds a week say three hundred for the sake of argument that's twelve hundred a month so it's about fourteen thousand a year and as I say it depends on your individual circumstances

but there is um so people get housing benefit and other benefits as well income support various other bits and pieces dependent on circumstances you can't it's not a blanket thing at all I mean we at the court we only get about a pound an hour more than the minimum wage
they can be working full-time and be
mm but there are huh there are lots of jobs that pay that much
or that little whichever way you want to look at it
so but then when you think back to what you were getting paid in Spain
yeah but that was by no means minimum wage because there were people on about half of what I was on
mm but compared to minimum wage earnings and what you were earning
there's not much difference is there?
yeah but you can't really make those comparisons across cultures

but then yours wasn't was it? Really
they got out of employing you on a permanent basis by making you
by because of the holidays over the summer
mm yeah so but I don't know but we've never considered um ushers us ushers that we're paid an awful lot I mean Laura was a full-time senior usher and I think she was on about seventeen thousand
so the Courts Service is not hugely paid
but it would be fine if people didn't have to fork out so much for r accommodation
and you pay less in on a mortgage than you do in rent provided you can stump up enough of a deposit
that's the ridiculous part about it and because people can't buy houses as easily as they used to be able to extra pressure on the rental market so the landlords hike the rents
but unfortunately it's the law of supply and demand isn't it
it's the cheekiness of some people to to er hike rents up
and hike prices up just because they can

mm well it's like the holiday industry that hikes prices in the school holidays because they know that a lot of people can only go in the school holidays so we hike the prices there's no economic reason for it other than they know that a lot of people have to take their holidays in that time
well it's even more it's even worse when you're talking about housing because shelter is supposed to be one of the human rights so if you've got people making profit out of

but then on the other hand people have bought houses have mortgages have to pay the mortgages so they have to charge rent to cover the mortgage they can't do it any other way unless you've got a spare
three hundred thousand quid to to spend

that the people who have bought the houses that people rent or the flats that people rent
have probably bought them on mortgages

be able to make a profit out of?

yeah er what I'm saying is that er housing shouldn't be for profit
yeah I know that's the problem

I just think it should be divorced from the idea of business there shouldn't be businesses that are making a profit from housing people because they'll they'll always start hiking prices up to make more profit and that's just
tis in the nature of the beast unfortunately

well they need to put some restrictions and regulations in place cos I'm sure the people who rent out their houses d and make profit they're pr yeah yeah but I should be able to do that it's my it's my right it's my house I can rent it out it's yeah fair enough but when you're creating the problem of hiking prices up and making tut you know making

again that needs to be changed as well that should be university run because the university last year um s sourced it out to another company
who was running all the student accommodation for profit because it's a business
and all of a sudden the refuse collection is cut to once every two weeks and I mean once every two weeks? You can imagine

with like twenty students for each bin no even more because there were three houses so thirty students for each bin and the bins are only collected once every fortnight it was disgusting and you s started getting rats
instead of having um a very basic but free internet connection

you know they're raking in a hundred and fifty on what they would in
a normal house probably only thirty or forty
so it just became for pr everything was for profit
you know where is the whole ethos
yeah unfortunately universities now don't have the funds to do what they used to do

I mean when you think back to when I was at college we paid nothing no tuition fees no board and lodging the education authority paid for all that but there was only a fraction of the number of pupils going to university or colleges as there are now
you know er you you can't have it both ways unfortunately
but I I still feel that universities should go back to being centres of academic e excellence

and have m far more vocational courses um because the majority not the majority but a large number of the people that they're sending to university shouldn't be there so they have Mickey Mouse degrees that are worth absolutely nothing doesn't enable them to get jobs and saddles them with a mountain of debt where's the logic in that?
it's ridiculous I'm still making up my mind to write to

because we missed Lakka um it was rather daunting experience so I we I mean it we laugh about it now
oh so it's not a letter of complaint? It's a
no no no this is my account of
oh I thought you said it was a letter

well it's got a very narrow entrance and then opens out into this big harbour type thing
and the very narrow entrance is not easy to see um unless you're very close to it and it didn't look like an entrance
it just looked like rocks and things so we missed it

and I was getting decidedly panicky because once you get round the tip of the island the terrain changes it's sheer sides um rocks absolutely nowhere to stop and all I wanted to do was to get off the bloody boat
I just wanted to get off

right on the water and you had somewhere to moor your motorboat so you could you could hire it for a week but I guess we can do the same we just have to go and fetch it and take it back every day cos there isn't anywhere cos we're slightly up above the the coast but it'll be fine
